1 Linear Model with quadratic features

The linear model with quadratic features is defined as

f(x)=α+∑kβkxk+∑kγkkx2k+∑k<lγklxkxl.f(x)=α+∑kβkxk+∑kγkkxk2+∑k<lγklxkxl.

There are no particular reason within the Use Case to utilise polynomial features but it is a popular and quite typical model. Even though this model is still rather simple, a proper allocation of variance poses challenges which are quite similar to those encountered in more complex models. There are three new issues:

  • What are the allocation targets? In contrast to the main effects model, the same variable now appears in different features (e.g. xixi in xixi, x2ixi2 and all mixed terms xixjxixj)
  • The question of dependence between features is now unavoidable. Even if inputs are stochastically independent the features will be dependent.
  • The sheer number of features is much larger: With dd input variables there are (d+1)+d+(d−1)d2(d+1)+d+(d−1)d2 features to deal with.

These issues will be addressed by Sobol-Indices, which rely on the functional ANOVA decomposition (see Section 8.4 of (Molnar 2022)).

2 Model fit

The main reason to introduce new features is to improve the fit. In the code below the model is repeatedly fit and its R2R2 calculated. To assess stability and to rule out excessive overfitting in and out of sample R2R2 is reported for several independent runs of the calibration. Note that we will fit the model on centred, i.e. mean zero, inputs. This is no loss of generality since the model remains quadratic.

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo=TRUE, cache = TRUE, cache.comments=FALSE, comment=NA, out.width="90%", attr.source=".numberLines")

suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(knitr))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(kableExtra))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(ggplot2))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(waterfalls))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(sensitivity))

# seed for reproducibility
set.seed(4711)
datadir = "./data/"

# Number of portfolio
ipf = 1

# data (.csv) files
fnm_xtrain = paste0(datadir,"Portfolio", ipf, "/train_input.csv")
fnm_ytrain = paste0(datadir,"Portfolio", ipf, "/train_result.csv")

xtrain = as.matrix(read.csv(fnm_xtrain)[,-1])

nxtrain = dim(xtrain)[1]
nrf = dim(xtrain)[2]
# names of input variables
nm_x = paste0("x", seq.int(1,nrf))
colnames(xtrain) = nm_x

# prepare response aka y
ytrain = as.matrix(read.csv(fnm_ytrain)[,-1])

# define formula for the interactions
tm_main = paste(nm_x, collapse = "+")
tm_quad = paste(paste0("I(", nm_x,"^2)"), collapse = "+")
tm = paste0("(", tm_main,"):(", tm_main,")")
fml = as.formula(paste0("y~", tm, "+", tm_quad))
fml_brev = as.formula(paste0("~ 0 + ", tm, "+", tm_quad))

# size of subset for the calibration
dessize = 4000

# number of iterations
niter = 10
rsq = array(Inf, dim=c(niter,3), dimnames = list(NULL, c("out", "in", "delta")) )
for(iiter in 1:niter){
  # select the points in the design
  tmp = sample.int(nxtrain, 2 * dessize, replace = FALSE)
  idxtrain = tmp[1:dessize]
  # select and centre the inputs
  x = scale(xtrain[idxtrain,], center = TRUE, scale = FALSE)
  y = ytrain[idxtrain]
  var_y = var(y)

  # test data for out-of-sample
  idxtest = tmp[-(1:dessize)]
  xtest = scale(xtrain[idxtest,], center = TRUE, scale = FALSE)
  ytest = ytrain[idxtest]
  var_ytest = var(ytest)

  # fit the model
  dfin = as.data.frame(cbind(y, x))
  md = lm( fml, dfin)
  # calculate Rsquareds
  rsq[iiter,"in"] = 1 - mean((y - md$fitted.values)^2) / var_y
  rsq[iiter, "out"] = 1 - mean((ytest - predict(md, as.data.frame(xtest)))^2) / var_ytest
}

rsq[,"delta"] = rsq[, "out"] - rsq[,"in"]
rsq = rbind(rsq,colMeans(rsq))
row.names(rsq) = c(rep("",niter), "mean")
kable_styling(kable(rsq*100, digits = 1,# row.names = TRUE,
          ), bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F)

3 Functional ANOVA decomposition

The functional ANOVA is a unique decomposition defined for every square-integrable function into uncorrelated elements onto which variance can be allocated. Thus solving two of the issues mentioned above. But it comes with a big disadvantage, this decomposition exists only for input variables which are stochastically independent. For this reason, we make the assumption of independent input variables in this section. The appropriateness of this assumption in light of the Use Case and the dependency in its input dataset will be discussed in Section 3.7.

3.1 Identification of components

Since the model now contains interactions between variables, we would like to distinguish between effects due to the various variable on their own (the main effects) and any impact some variables may have due to their interactions with other variables. This is achieved by decomposing the function ff into additive components, such that the components only depend on single variables, on two variables etc. But a function can be decomposed into a sum in many different ways, which raises the question of uniqueness of the decomposition. Since we would like to attribute something to the components which is supposed to have an objective meaning, we need to make sure that the components are not arbitrary. This is non-trivial already in the simple and explicitly given linear model with interacting features above. While the model is already split into a sum of components and these components either stand on their own or interact, this decomposition is not unique. For the simple model

f(x)=x1+x1x2=(x1+1)x2f(x)=x1+x1x2=(x1+1)x2
it is not clear whether ff has a main effect x1x1 and interaction x1x2x1x2 or consists of a pure interaction effect (x1+1)x2(x1+1)x2 only. This question can get more complicated quickly. For all a,b∈Ra,b∈R:
1+x1+x2+x1x2=(1−ab)+(1+a)x1+(1+b)x2+(1−a)x1(1−b)x2.1+x1+x2+x1x2=(1−ab)+(1+a)x1+(1+b)x2+(1−a)x1(1−b)x2.

Both decompositions will have exactly the same predictions and are indistinguishable in a black-box setting. But even when having access to the function, any explanation which relies only on coefficients is in danger of being arbitrary.1

3.2 Definition and basic properties of the functional ANOVA

Let X=(X1,…,Xd)X=(X1,…,Xd) denote the random input variables, For a subset u=(j1,…,jk)⊂{1,…,d}u=(j1,…,jk)⊂{1,…,d} denote by Xu=(Xj1,…,Xjk)Xu=(Xj1,…,Xjk) the according subset of the input variables and write

E[f(X)|Xu]=E[f(X)|(Xj1,…,Xjk)]E[f(X)|Xu]=E[f(X)|(Xj1,…,Xjk)]

for the conditional expectation. Note that E[f(X)|Xu]E[f(X)|Xu] is a function depending only on the kk variables Xu=(Xj1,…,Xjk)Xu=(Xj1,…,Xjk). Set f∅=E[f]f∅=E[f] and define

fu(Xu)=E[f(X)|Xu]−∑v⊊ufv(Xv).fu(Xu)=E[f(X)|Xu]−∑v⊊ufv(Xv).
The functional ANOVA decomposition is the sum of these components over all possible subsets of variables
f(X)=∑u⊂{1,…,d}fu(Xu).f(X)=∑u⊂{1,…,d}fu(Xu).

The decomposition has the following properties:

  • It exists for all ff with finite variance.
  • It is unique.
  • All components with u≠∅u≠∅ have zero mean: E[fu]=0.E[fu]=0.
  • For all k∈u:∫fu(Xu)dXk=0k∈u:∫fu(Xu)dXk=0 and for all v⊂u:E[fu|Xv]=0.v⊂u:E[fu|Xv]=0.
  • The different components are uncorrelated E[fufv]=0E[fufv]=0 for all u≠v.u≠v.

For a proof and additional properties of the decomposition see (Kuo et al. (2010)). A concise summary including related results can be found in Owen.

3.3 Sobol indices

Due to the uncorrelatedness and uniqueness of all components of the sum, the variance of ff allows the unique decomposition

V[f(X)]=∑u⊂{1,…,d}V[fu(xu)].V[f(X)]=∑u⊂{1,…,d}V[fu(xu)].
As done before one can normalise by the variance of ff to obtain
1=∑u⊂{1,…,d}Su1=∑u⊂{1,…,d}Su
 where
Su=V[fu]V[f]Su=V[fu]V[f]
 is the Sobol index of the inputs Xu.Xu. Since they are variances of uncorrelated components the Sobol indices have the properties of a decomposition:

  • Each Sobol index is non-negative: 0≤Su.0≤Su.
  • The indices sum to one: ∑uSu=1.∑uSu=1.

But Sobol indices do not solve the third issue mentioned above: There are in total 2d2d of them. This means for our Use Case d=d= 13 and 2d=2d= 8192 which is clearly not a practical number. This is why in practice only the main effects or first order Sobol indices, i.e. the indices where u={i}u={i} is a singleton,

Si=V[E[f|Xi]]V[f] for all i=1,…,d(3.1)(3.1)Si=V[E[f|Xi]]V[f] for all i=1,…,d

are studied together with the total Sobol indices

Ti=∑u⊂{1,…,d}i∈uSu for all i=1,…,d.Ti=∑u⊂{1,…,d}i∈uSu for all i=1,…,d.

Each SiSi captures the main effect attributable to XiXi, while TiTi captures the effects of XiXi including all its interactions with other variables, pairwise as well as those of higher order.

Main and total Sobol indices have those useful properties:

  • ∑Si≤1∑Si≤1 and ∑Si=1∑Si=1 if and only if ff is a purely additive function.
  • 1−∑Si1−∑Si is a measure of the amount of interaction in ff.
  • Si≤TiSi≤Ti and Si=TiSi=Ti means again a purely additive model without interactions.
  • Ti=0Ti=0 means the variable XiXi has no influence on ff at all.

3.4 Further properties of the functional ANOVA decomposition

Many key concepts are more or less directly related to and can be easily derived from the functional ANOVA decomposition.

3.4.1 Effective dimension

How the variance of a target function is distributed over terms of low and high interaction defines a natural measure of the complexity of a function. The effective dimension in the superposition sense is defined for a suitable cutoff δ>0δ>0 as the smallest integer nn such that

∑#u≤nu⊂{1…,d}Su≥1−δ∑#u≤nu⊂{1…,d}Su≥1−δ
where #u#u is the number of elements in uu. A small effective dimension means you need only few inputs, in particular only few interactions, to explain the variance of ff up to a prespecified accuracy. Accordingly a function with small effective dimension is inherently simpler to explain than a function with large effective dimension.

3.4.2 Partial dependence plots

1-Dimensional Partial dependence plots (Molnar (2022) Chapter 8.1) are the plots of the uncentred main order functional ANOVA components f{i}(Xi)+f∅f{i}(Xi)+f∅ and analogous statements are true for higher dimensions.

3.4.3 Permutation Feature Importance

If all input variables are independent, i.e. if the functional ANOVA decomposition exists, and if the loss function is least squares, Permutation Feature Importance (Molnar (2022), Chapter 8.5) is closely related to total Sobol indices. In fact, if the feature space of a model is closed under integration, which is quite a natural condition in many cases, Permutation Feature Importance of an input jj is just twice the non-normalised total Sobol index

PFI(Xj)=2Tj∗V[f].PFI(Xj)=2Tj∗V[f].

A proof of this can be found in the Appendix 5.1.

3.4.4 Approximation property of Sobol indices

Sobol indices, respectively the functional ANOVA decomposition from which the indices are derived, are model agnostic. Not only because they can be computed for any model ff but also because they provide a consistent framework for all functions which satisfy the assumptions of the existence of the functional ANOVA. This is actually useful in practice because it enables the user to gain information from one model and draw conclusions about all other possible models. This useful property can be summarised succinctly as:

  • If two models have high R2R2 for the same underlying response they have similar Sobol indices.
  • If a model has high R2R2 its Sobol indices are close to the “true” Sobol indices, i.e. those of the underlying response.

The discussion in Appendix 5.2 will provide evidence for these statements and derive computable quantitative bounds not only for single indices such as the first order indices but for any grouping of indices as well 2.

3.5 Functional ANOVA decomposition for quadratic features

In most cases Sobol indices will be estimated by Monte Carlo methods and we will cover this in the next chapter. But the linear model with quadratic features is simple enough so that one can calculate the decomposition explicitly. This is impossible for general models, for example because the internal structure of the model may be inaccessible and even if it is accessible, the required conditional expectations may be impossible to compute. Nevertheless, it is quite illuminating to go through this exercise for quadratic features since it clarifies the abstract concepts and provides a base case to validate the Monte Carlo estimates.

Observe that under our assumptions i.e. independent and centred XkXk

f∅=E[f]=α+∑kγkkE[X2k].f∅=E[f]=α+∑kγkkE[Xk2].

The conditional expectations are also straightforward:

E[Xk|Xi]={E[Xk]=0Xi if k≠i if k=iE[Xk|Xi]={E[Xk]=0 if k≠iXi if k=i
as well as
E[X2k|Xi]={E[X2k]X2i if k≠i if k=i.E[Xk2|Xi]={E[Xk2] if k≠iXi2 if k=i.

Furthermore with 1,…,i<j,…,d:1,…,i<j,…,d:

E[Xk|Xi,Xj]=⎧⎩⎨0XiXj if k∉{i,j} if i=k if j=k.E[Xk|Xi,Xj]={0 if k∉{i,j}Xi if i=kXj if j=k.

Due to the mutual independence of all XkXk it follows that E[XkXl|Xi]=E[Xk|Xi]E[Xl|Xi]E[XkXl|Xi]=E[Xk|Xi]E[Xl|Xi] and

E[f|Xi]=α+βiXi+γiiX2i+∑k≠iγkkE[X2k].E[f|Xi]=α+βiXi+γiiXi2+∑k≠iγkkE[Xk2].
This means the first order components are
fi=E[f|Xi]−f∅=βiXi+γiiX2i−γiiE[X2i].fi=E[f|Xi]−f∅=βiXi+γiiXi2−γiiE[Xi2].

In the same way one can conclude that

E[f|Xi,Xj]=α+βiXi+βjXj+γiiX2i+γjjX2j+∑k∉{i,j}γkkE[X2k]+γijXiXjE[f|Xi,Xj]=α+βiXi+βjXj+γiiXi2+γjjXj2+∑k∉{i,j}γkkE[Xk2]+γijXiXj

and

fij=E[f|Xi,Xj]−fi−fj−f∅=γijXiXj.fij=E[f|Xi,Xj]−fi−fj−f∅=γijXiXj.

The higher order components have to be zero because first and second order components already sum up to the total function:

∑i<jfij+∑ifi+f∅=f.∑i<jfij+∑ifi+f∅=f.

Since we are working with the empirical measure given by the selected training dataset, the variances needed to obtain the first order Sobol indices are easily computed as empirical variances. The total Sobol indices are then:

Ti=Si+∑i≠jSij.Ti=Si+∑i≠jSij.

# fit the model (on the dependent inputs)
idxtrain = sample.int(nxtrain, dessize, replace = FALSE)
# select and centre the inputs
x = scale(xtrain[idxtrain,], center = TRUE, scale = FALSE)
y = ytrain[idxtrain]

dfin = as.data.frame(cbind(y, x))
md = lm( fml, dfin)

# the sequence of coefficients is: (alpha, betas, gamma_ii, gamma_ij)  
cf = md$coefficients[-1]
nm_cf = names(cf)

# create design matrix, same sequence of columns as coefficients
# shuffle the rows in each column to create independent variables 
x_indep = x
for(icol in 1:dim(x_indep)[2]){
  permu = sample.int(dessize, size = dessize, replace = FALSE)
  x_indep[,icol] = x[permu, icol]
}

# calculate variance of f on independent inputs
var_f = var(predict(md, newdata = as.data.frame(x_indep)))

# fml_brev is without intercept
modmat = model.matrix(fml_brev, as.data.frame(x_indep))

v_i = array(0, dim=c(nrf), dimnames = list(nm_cf[1:nrf]))
for(ifeat in 1:nrf){
  v_i[ifeat] = var(modmat[, ifeat] * cf[ifeat] + modmat[,nrf + ifeat]*cf[nrf + ifeat])
}

# variance of f_ij
# number of mixed columns x_1 x_j with i<j
n_ij = nrf * (nrf - 1)/2
v_ij = array(0, dim = n_ij, 
             dimnames = list(nm_cf[2 * nrf + seq.int(1, n_ij)]))
# loop over the remaining columns of the design matrix containing the mixed features
for(iidx in seq.int(1, n_ij)){
    v_ij[iidx] = var(modmat[, 2 * nrf + iidx] * cf[2 * nrf + iidx])
}

# Sobol indices

# first order
S = v_i / var_f
# to simplify the addition for T put all v_ij in a matrix as two triangles
S_ij = array(0, dim = c(nrf, nrf))
S_ij[lower.tri(S_ij, diag = FALSE)] = v_ij
S_ij = S_ij + t(S_ij)
S_ij = S_ij / var_f

# total Sobol indices
TT = S + colSums(S_ij)

st = cbind(S, TT)
df_st = round(as.data.frame(st) * 100, 1)
cstmp = round(colSums(st) * 100,1)
df_st = rbind(df_st, cstmp)
dimnames(df_st) = list(c(nm_x, "total"), c("S", "T"))
df_st["total", "T"] = ""

# all S_ij
df = round(as.data.frame(S_ij) * 100, 1)
diag(df)=""
rstmp = round(rowSums(S_ij) * 100,1)
# prepend col with row sums and append row with grand total S_ij and empty
df = rbind(cbind(rstmp, df), c(round(sum(S_ij) / 2 * 100,1), rep("", nrf)))
dimnames(df) = list(c(nm_x, "total"), c("total row", nm_x))

kable_styling(kable(cbind(df_st,df), caption = "$R^2$ allocated on all components"), bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F)

3.6 Monte Carlo Estimation for Sobol indices

Since their introduction by I. Sobol in the early nineties, much time and effort went into refining and improving estimates for Sobol indices. The package sensitivity alone covers 11 different approaches. Here just the basic idea will be discussed and a simple implementation provided as a proof-of-concept. More and in-depth information can be found in the references contained in the package sensitivity or from the paper (Saltelli et al. (2010)).

Start with the definition of SiSi in equation (3.1). Since it is straightforward to estimate V[f]V[f] the challenge is to find a Monte Carlo estimate for the variance of the conditional expectations V[E[f|Xi]].V[E[f|Xi]]. Since

V[E[f|Xi]]=E[E[f|Xi]2]−E[E[f|Xi]]2V[E[f|Xi]]=E[E[f|Xi]2]−E[E[f|Xi]]2
and
E[E[f|Xi]]=E[f]E[E[f|Xi]]=E[f]
 which is again easy to estimate, it suffices to find an estimator for the first term on the right hand side. Recall that the conditional expectation E[f|Xi]E[f|Xi] is the d−1d−1 dimensional integral over all marginal distributions of the variables XkXk except XiXi, which shall be denoted by dx−idx−i, i.e.
E[f|Xi]=∫f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)dx−i.E[f|Xi]=∫f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)dx−i.
 A clever “trick” is now to observe that the square of this expression can be written as the following 2(d−1)2(d−1) dimension integral
E[f|Xi]2=E[f|Xi]E[f|Xi]=∫f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)f(x′1,…,x′i−1,xi,x′i+1,…,x′d)dx−idx′−i.E[f|Xi]2=E[f|Xi]E[f|Xi]=∫f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)f(x1′,…,xi−1′,xi,xi+1′,…,xd′)dx−idx′−i.
 Integrating this expression over the only remaining variable xixi yields
E[E[f|Xi]2]=∫E[f|Xi]2dxi=∫∫f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)f(x′1,…,x′i−1,xi,x′i+1,…,x′d)dx−idx′−idxi.E[E[f|Xi]2]=∫E[f|Xi]2dxi=∫∫f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)f(x1′,…,xi−1′,xi,xi+1′,…,xd′)dx−idx′−idxi.
 Note that dxidxi can be combined with dx−idx−i such that this double integral can be written as a single integral with respect to the product measure dxdx′idxdx′i over the 2d−12d−1 variables of the function
f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)f(x′1,…,x′i−1,xi,x′i+1,…,x′d).f(x1,…,xi,…,xd)f(x1′,…,xi−1′,xi,xi+1′,…,xd′).
 But this is just a single integral which can be estimated by Monte Carlo by splitting the input dataset into two independent sets XX and X′X′ of size NN and applying the estimate

V^i=1N∑j=1Nf(x(j)1,…,x(j)i,…,x(j)d)f(x′(j)1,…,x′(j)i−1,x(j)i,x′(j)i+1,…,x′(j)d)−1N∑j=1Nf(x(j)1,…,x(j)i,…,x(j)d)2.V^i=1N∑j=1Nf(x1(j),…,xi(j),…,xd(j))f(x1′(j),…,xi−1′(j),xi(j),xi+1′(j),…,xd′(j))−1N∑j=1Nf(x1(j),…,xi(j),…,xd(j))2.
The following code block implements this estimation procedure.

# squared expected value E[f]^2
fmeansq = mean(predict(md, newdata = as.data.frame(x_indep)))^2

# split the inputs into two sets of equal size n
n = dessize / 2
x_1 = x_indep[1:n,]
f_1 = predict(md, newdata = as.data.frame(x_1))
x_2 = x_indep[-(1:n),]

# Calculate each v_i but this time using mc 
vi_mc = array(0, dim=c(nrf), dimnames = list(nm_cf[1:nrf]))
for(icol in 1:nrf){
  mixmat = x_2
  mixmat[,icol] = x_1[,icol]
  f_mix = predict(md, newdata = as.data.frame(mixmat))
  vi_mc[icol] = mean(f_mix * f_1) - fmeansq  
}

Si_mc = vi_mc / var_f

df = round(data.frame(S, Si_mc) * 100,1)
dimnames(df) = list(c(nm_x), c("analytic", "DIY MC"))
kable_styling(kable( df, 
     caption = "First order Sobol indices for quadratic features"),
  bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F)

x12 0.1 2.2
x13 4.7 8.8

Note that the MC estimate just requires calls to the predict function as sole information about the model. Accordingly it is model agnostic and works without knowledge of the internal structure.

With further clever combinations of the inputs the total Sobol indices can be calculated in a similar way and quite efficiently, see the references for details. For first order and total Sobol indices together only N(d+2)N(d+2) evaluations of ff are required. The next table shows SS and TT calculated with the package sensitivity which uses an improved estimator.

# we need a predict function with correct formula

  model.matrix(fml, as.data.frame(xin)) %*% cf
}

mdpredict = function(xin){
  tmppredict(fml_brev, md$coefficients[-1], xin)
}

tt = soboljansen(mdpredict, as.data.frame(x_1), as.data.frame(x_2))

3.7 Are independent inputs appropriate or useful?

The functional ANOVA decomposition nicely illustrates the fundamental problem with dependent and independent inputs. The main effects function f1f1 is a function which “only depends on” X1X1 in the sense that it can be written as f1=f1(X1)f1=f1(X1) without reference to any other inputs. But if X1X1 and X7X7 are not independent then in general E[f1(X1)|X7]=h(X7)E[f1(X1)|X7]=h(X7) will be a non-constant function of X7X7 and in this sense f1(X1)f1(X1) is not a function of X1X1 alone. The stochastic dependence creates an interaction even though the function itself contains none. This also explains why the idea to “only change X1X1 while everything else remains the same” is just not possible. So from this perspective the answer is probably a resounding no: Independent inputs make no sense! In light of this fact, all versions of statements such as “GAMs/additive models are interpretable” should be taken with a grain of salt as long as the underlying input distribution is not fully specified, understood and sufficiently simple. This of course is likewise true for all methods which implicitly assume independence such as methods which rely on permuting features.

On the other hand it is true that some partial information can be gained from analysis under the independence assumption. For prediction one only cares about f(X)f(X) with the given/observed dependent joint input distribution XX. But for explanation/interpretation you need to distinguish between ff and the inputs because you need to explain the output in terms of the inputs or simple features derived from those. From this distinction arises the utility of analysis under independence assumptions. Although the distribution of f(Z)f(Z) under independent inputs ZZ will be quite different from the distribution of f(X)f(X), the former can be used to gain information about ff as a (deterministic) function f:Rd→R.f:Rd→R. This is a bit like studying the payout of a complex derivative without caring about the underlying or like analysing the terms of a reinsurance contract without description of the underlying portfolio. For the following reasons analysing ff under an independent input distribution ZZ may be a useful tool:

  • It allows for the functional ANOVA decomposition, which makes the structure of ff itself transparent.
  • It provides a means to summarise the complex behaviour of ff into a few statistics, such as the allocated amounts of variance.

That said, the analyst should be aware of and deal with all issues which this ensues:

  • The method allocates the variance of f(Z)f(Z) which is quite different from the original variance of f(X)f(X). Note, that in line 23 of the code block directly before Table 3.1 a new variance is calculated and that all subsequent R2R2 which follow refer to this variance not the original one.
  • Independent inputs may create “impossible data”. You may predict for an annuity which starts before the insured is born or develop reserves for losses where the accident year is before the underwriting year3.
  • Even if the data is not logically impossible, the new measure will reweigh all observations. The variance and its allocation may be determined by areas of the input space where the model has seen almost no training data and which are completely irrelevant for the application.

In conclusion, while definitely not completely useless, independent analysis is dangerous. One reason why it is still so popular, may be the fact that alternative solutions come with their own problems.

4 Shapley allocation

Even for the simple quadratic model the allocation of variance according to the Shapley algorithm poses several challenges:

  • Any distinction between main and interaction features has to be reflected in the definition of possible coalitions. Shall an interaction term fijfij be grouped together with fifi with fjfj or is it a new and different target?
  • As mentioned before, the number of calculations grows exponentially with the number of targets. This limits severely the number of possible targets for the allocation.
  • What is an appropriate value function? The natural candidate in light of the ANOVA decomposition above, were the conditional variances V[E[f|Xu]]V[E[f|Xu]]. But these are exceedingly difficult to calculate if the only available information about the inputs are independent samples from the joint distribution of XX.

Here, the same approach as in the first part will be adopted, i.e. the attribution of variance explained by the Shapley algorithm, which means incremental R2R2 as the value function.

It would be an excellent idea to inform the choice of allocation targets by domain knowledge about the underlying actuarial model of the risk factors. For reasons explained before this is impossible here. A pragmatic choice informed by the prior results on main effects and the independent decomposition is to combine the features into a few groups to reduce the overall number of inputs. These targets are calculated by splitting the inputs into four non-overlapping categories: x1x1, x7x7, x13x13 and one group containing all remaining inputs. Each combination of input variables has all quadratic features made up of those variables.

# all rsquared will be tested on fresh oos
idxdes_sh = sample.int(nxtrain, dessize, replace = FALSE)
# select and centre the inputs
x_sh = scale(xtrain[idxdes_sh,], center = TRUE, scale = FALSE)
y_sh = ytrain[idxdes_sh]
var_ysh = var(y_sh)

# define groups
tmp = list(x1=1, x7=7, x13=13)
grp = c(tmp, list(rest = setdiff(1:nrf, unlist(tmp))))
ngrp = length(grp)
nm_grp = names(grp)

# subsets are coded as binary vectors
# make logical matrix of all possible subsets for retrieval of results
# note: indices are one-based while binary numbers start with zero (= empty set)
inclmat = array(FALSE, dim = c(2^ngrp, ngrp), dimnames = list(NULL, nm_grp))
# holds the r2 value of the respective included groups
r2mat = numeric(dim(inclmat)[2])
# no group/empty set has R2 of zero
r2mat[1] = 0

for(isubgrp in 2:2^ngrp){
  
  inclmat[isubgrp,] = as.logical(intToBits(isubgrp - 1))[1:ngrp]
  
  # included variables
  invar = unlist(grp[inclmat[isubgrp, ]])
  
  # (re) fit the model, on original data, but new subset of variables
  
  # define formula for features
  nm_var = nm_x[invar]
  tm_main = paste(nm_var, collapse = "+")
  tm_quad = paste(paste0("I(", nm_var,"^2)"), collapse = "+")
  tm = paste0("(", tm_main,"):(", tm_main,")")
  fml = as.formula(paste0("y~", tm, "+", tm_quad))
  
  md = lm(fml, data.frame(y=y, x[,invar,drop=FALSE]))
  
  # calculate Rsquared
  ypred = predict(md, data.frame(x_sh[, invar, drop=FALSE]))
  r2mat[isubgrp] = 1 - mean((y_sh - ypred)^2) / var_ysh
}

# sum up properly weighted differences per group
fgrp = factorial(ngrp)
val_sh = numeric(ngrp)

for(igrp in 1:ngrp){
  
  # find all subsets where current group is included
  flg_in = inclmat[,igrp]
  # associate rsquared where current group is included with the other members
  tt_in = cbind(inclmat[flg_in, -igrp], r2mat[flg_in])
  # associated rsquared where group was not included
  tt_out = cbind(inclmat[!flg_in, -igrp], r2mat[!flg_in])
  # join over all other members except current group
  ttt = merge(tt_in, tt_out, by = nm_grp[-igrp])
  colnames(ttt) = c(nm_grp[-igrp], "R2in", "R2out")
  # number of members
  nS = rowSums(ttt[,1:ngrp - 1])
  # see the formula in Gröning for the coefficients
  coeff = factorial(nS) * factorial(ngrp - nS - 1) / fgrp
  val_sh[igrp] = coeff %*% (ttt[,"R2in"] - ttt[,"R2out"])
}

df = data.frame(values = round(c(val_sh) * 100,1),
                labels=c(nm_grp) )
print(waterfall( df, calc_total = TRUE, total_axis_text = "explained") )

data_quad = c(data_quad, list(shapley=val_sh))
# store for later import into third report
saveRDS(data_quad, paste0(datadir, "export_quadratic.RDS"))

5 Appendix: further theory

This Section provides further analysis of the theory behind the approximation property and the relation between total Sobol indices and Permutation Feature Importance. The available literature did not provide a reference but the statements seem relevant. They are relegated to the Appendix, since they are not necessary for immediate applications.

5.1 Permutation Feature Importance and total Sobol index

5.1.1 Permutation versus independent draws

Permutation Feature Importance is defined in (Molnar 2022, chap. 8.5) as ” the increase in the prediction error of the model after we permuted the feature’s values”. Prediction error after permuting means recalculating the mean squared error when an original input instance is replaced with one of the remaining N−1N−1 instances of the sample. Since this definition excludes drawing the same attribute twice it is slightly different from independent redraws. To simplify the following argument, we redefine Permutation Importance slightly and assume independent draws from the empirical marginal distributions. The difference between independent draws and permutations is obviously negligible, if the size NN of the dataset is sufficiently large. Hence we define the permutation feature importance of input jj as

PFI(j)=E[(y−f(X(j)))2]−E[(y−f(X))2]PFI(j)=E[(y−f(X(j)))2]−E[(y−f(X))2]

where X=(X1,…,Xd)X=(X1,…,Xd) are the original inputs as defined by the dataset and X(j)X(j) denotes the vector where all inputs are the same as XX except the one input XjXj which is replaced by a copy X′jXj′. The X′jXj′ copy has the same (marginal) distribution as XjXj but is independent from all XiXi with i≠ji≠j and is in addition also independent from the response yy. All expectations are taken with respect to the joint probability distribution (y,X1,…,Xd,X′j).(y,X1,…,Xd,Xj′). Recall that we assume throughout that all XiXi are mutually independent as well.

5.1.2 Relationship to total Sobol indices

Replace in the definition above y−f(X(j))y−f(X(j)) by (y−f(X))+(f(X)−f(X(j)))(y−f(X))+(f(X)−f(X(j))) cancel the terms E[(y−f(X(j)))2]E[(y−f(X(j)))2] to obtain

PFI(j)=E[(f(X)−f(X(j)))2]−2E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))].(5.1)(5.1)PFI(j)=E[(f(X)−f(X(j)))2]−2E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))].

Apply the functional ANOVA decomposition to f(X)f(X) and f(X(j))f(X(j)) and notice that

 For all u⊂{1,…,d} with j∉u:fu(X)=fu(X(j)). For all u⊂{1,…,d} with j∉u:fu(X)=fu(X(j)).
This means that all terms of the decomposition which do not contain jj cancel and
f(X)−f(X(j))=∑j∉uu⊂{1,…,d}f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,X′j).f(X)−f(X(j))=∑j∉uu⊂{1,…,d}f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,Xj′).

To determine E[(f(X)−f(X(j)))2]E[(f(X)−f(X(j)))2] expand the square with the decomposition above and observe that all “mixed” terms are orthogonal, i.e. if v≠uv≠u then

E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,X′j))(f(v,j)(Xv,Xj)−f(v,j)(Xv,X′j))]=0.E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,Xj′))(f(v,j)(Xv,Xj)−f(v,j)(Xv,Xj′))]=0.
which follows directly from the orthogonality property E[fu(xu)fv(xv)]=0E[fu(xu)fv(xv)]=0 for u≠vu≠v of the functional ANOVA decomposition.

The only terms remaining are terms where u=vu=v, i.e. 

E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,X′j))2]E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,Xj′))2]
but this can again be expanded and - after cancelling mixed terms again - written as

E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj))2]+E[(f(u,j)(Xu,X′j))2].E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj))2]+E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj′))2].
Since XjXj and X′jXj′ have the same distribution this is just
2E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj))2].2E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj))2].

In total

E[(f(X)−f(X(j)))2]=∑j∉uu⊂{1,…,d}E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,X′j))2]=2∑j∉uu⊂{1,…,d}E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj))2]=2TjV[f].E[(f(X)−f(X(j)))2]=∑j∉uu⊂{1,…,d}E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj)−f(u,j)(Xu,Xj′))2]=2∑j∉uu⊂{1,…,d}E[(f(u,j)(Xu,Xj))2]=2TjV[f].

5.1.3 Conditions for E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))]=0E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))]=0

It remains to show respectively to clarify under what conditions the remaining term in equation (5.1)

E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))]=0.E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))]=0.

Note first that this is not always true. The following provides a simple counterexample. Assume the input space is two-dimensional [−12,12]2[−12,12]2 with the independent uniform measure. The target function is

y(X1,X2)=X1y(X1,X2)=X1
and the feature space for regression is one-dimensional F={γX1X22|γ∈R}.F={γX1X22|γ∈R}. A straightforward calculation produces the least squares optimal regression coefficient γ=203γ=203. Accordingly the regression function is f(X1,X2)=203X1X22f(X1,X2)=203X1X22. Since the regression function ff contains X2X2 the total Sobol index of variable X2X2 can not be zero:
T2≠0.T2≠0.

On the other hand X2X2 is independent from y(X1,X2)=X1y(X1,X2)=X1, which means that permutations of X2X2 or exchanging X2X2 with an identically distributed copy X′X′ which is independent from yy does not change the mean squared error and the Permutation Feature Importance has to be zero:

PFI(2)=E[(X1−203X1X22)2]−E[(X1−203X1(X′)2)2]=0.PFI(2)=E[(X1−203X1X22)2]−E[(X1−203X1(X′)2)2]=0.
To understand what goes wrong and to define an appropriate sufficient condition, observe that the regression residuals y−fy−f are always orthogonal to ff and accordingly
E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))]=E[(y−f(X))f(X(j))].E[(y−f(X))(f(X)−f(X(j)))]=E[(y−f(X))f(X(j))].

After applying the functional ANOVA decomposition to f(X(j))f(X(j)) one can use the fact that X′jXj′ is independent from yy and ff to integrate out all terms of the decomposition which involve the variable X′jXj′:

E[(y−f(X))f(X(j))]=E⎡⎣(y−f(X))∑u⊂{1,…,d}fu(X(j)u)⎤⎦=E⎡⎣∫((y−f(X))∑u⊂{1,…,d}fu(X(j)u))dX′j⎤⎦=E⎡⎣(y−f(X))∑u⊂{1,…,d}∫(fu(X(j)u))dX′j⎤⎦=E⎡⎣⎢⎢(y−f(X))∑i∉uu⊂{1,…,d}fu(Xu)⎤⎦⎥⎥.E[(y−f(X))f(X(j))]=E[(y−f(X))∑u⊂{1,…,d}fu(X(j)u)]=E[∫((y−f(X))∑u⊂{1,…,d}fu(X(j)u))dXj′]=E[(y−f(X))∑u⊂{1,…,d}∫(fu(X(j)u))dXj′]=E[(y−f(X))∑i∉uu⊂{1,…,d}fu(Xu)].
where for the last line the property of the functional ANOVA decomposition was used that
 For all k∈u:∫fu(Xu)dXk=0. For all k∈u:∫fu(Xu)dXk=0.

As the counterexample above showed, this orthogonality condition for single ANOVA terms fufu need not always hold. It does hold if the feature space is closed under integration. This means that for any feature function ϕ(X1,…,Xd)ϕ(X1,…,Xd) and every subset u⊂{1,…,d}u⊂{1,…,d} the integrated feature ∫ϕ(X1,…,Xd)dXu∫ϕ(X1,…,Xd)dXu is again an element of the feature space. Since the residuals of a least squares fit are orthogonal to the whole feature space, they are automatically orthogonal to the fufu as well since those are linear combinations of the features.

For polynomial features this is fulfilled, if the feature space contains all lower order interactions and main effects, if it contains a high order polynomial. This is exactly what went wrong in the counterexample, the feature space contains the third order interaction X1X22X1X22 but it does not contain the lower order main effects X1X1, X2X2 and X1X2.X1X2. The same is true for tree based models since integrals of trees are again trees. It may not necessarily hold for all Gaussian Process Regression models.

5.2 Approximation property

5.2.1 Defining groups of indices

In the following ff denotes the known function/model and yy either the unknown underlying true function or just any other model. Let UU be any non-empty set of subsets of {1,…,d}{1,…,d}. UU may be a singleton U={i}U={i} for a main effect or a set such as {{1,i},{2,i},…,{d,i}}{{1,i},{2,i},…,{d,i}} for the total Sobol index TiTi. Its complement in the set of subsets is U¯U¯. Now ff and yy can be split into two parts each:

f1=∑u∈Ufu and f2=∑u∈U¯fuf1=∑u∈Ufu and f2=∑u∈U¯fu
and
y1=∑u∈Uyu and y2=∑u∈U¯yu.y1=∑u∈Uyu and y2=∑u∈U¯yu.

Do to the uncorrelatedness of the terms of the ANOVA decomposition the variance split as well

V[f]=V[f1]+V[f2] and V[y]=V[y1]+V[y2].V[f]=V[f1]+V[f2] and V[y]=V[y1]+V[y2].

The Sobol indices of ff and yy associated with UU are

Sf1=V[f1]V[f],Sf2=V[f2]V[f] and Sy1=V[y1]V[y],Sy2=V[y2]V[y].S1f=V[f1]V[f],S2f=V[f2]V[f] and S1y=V[y1]V[y],S2y=V[y2]V[y].

5.2.2 The closeness constraint

The “closeness” of ff and yy is defined in terms of R2R2. This means ff is close to yy if ff has an R2R2 for yy close to 100% or

R2=1−E[(f−y)2]V[f]≥1−δ where 0≤δ≪1R2=1−E[(f−y)2]V[f]≥1−δ where 0≤δ≪1
or equivalently
E[(f−y)2]≤δ2V[f]2 where 0≤δ≪1.(5.2)(5.2)E[(f−y)2]≤δ2V[f]2 where 0≤δ≪1.

Note, that R2R2 is here defined slightly different from the usual way. It is defined relative to the known model ff not in terms of the empirical variance of the unknown function yy as it is normally done. This is done to make the bounds computable in terms of known quantities. To simplify notation and to emphasise the geometric nature of the subsequent arguments, we use the norm notation, i.e. write E[g2]=∥g∥2E[g2]=‖g‖2 for functions gg which are square integrable with respect to the underlying measure.

To get rid of the constant terms, use the functional ANOVA decomposition to split the functions orthogonally into a constant and the non-constant rest f=f∅+f~f=f∅+f~, y=y∅+y~y=y∅+y~. But this means

δ2V[f]=∥∥f~∥∥2≥∥∥y~+y∅−f~−f∅∥∥2=∥∥y~−f~∥∥2+(y∅−f∅)2≥∥∥y~−f~∥∥2.δ2V[f]=‖f~‖2≥‖y~+y∅−f~−f∅‖2=‖y~−f~‖2+(y∅−f∅)2≥‖y~−f~‖2.

In other words: If functions ff and yy are close, their zero mean versions will be close as well. In addition, the Sobol indices themselves are defined using variance and accordingly invariant under adding a constant. This means bounds for the zero mean versions will also be bounds for the original functions. Hence we can assume without loss of generality that ff and yy are zero mean.

5.2.3 Angles

The Sobol indices for a group UU and its complement U¯U¯ as defined above are non-negative and sum up to one. This means we can define angles ϕϕ and ψψ with 0≤ϕ,ψ≤π20≤ϕ,ψ≤π2 such that:

cosϕ=Sf1−−√=∥f1∥∥f∥ and sinϕ=Sf2−−√=∥f2∥∥f∥cos⁡ϕ=S1f=‖f1‖‖f‖ and sin⁡ϕ=S2f=‖f2‖‖f‖
cosψ=Sy1−−√=∥y1∥∥y∥ and sinψ=Sy2−−√=∥y2∥∥y∥.cos⁡ψ=S1y=‖y1‖‖y‖ and sin⁡ψ=S2y=‖y2‖‖y‖.
 Since coscos is decreasing on [0,π2][0,π2] bounding Sy1S1y from above amounts to making the angle ψψ as small as possible and for the lower bound as large as possible.

5.2.4 Bounds for Sy1S1y

The task is now to find upper and lower bounds forSy1S1y under the closeness constraint (5.2) for ff and yy. We will connect the angle with the closeness constraint by writing y=f+dy=f+d for a suitable dd and split this into orthogonal parts y1=f1+d1y1=f1+d1 and y2=f2+d2y2=f2+d2 using the functional ANOVA decomposition. This can then be written as

cotψ=∥y1∥∥y2∥=∥f1+d1∥∥f2+d2∥.cot⁡ψ=‖y1‖‖y2‖=‖f1+d1‖‖f2+d2‖.
This quotient respectively cotψcot⁡ψ can be directly connected to cosψcos⁡ψ. Since both functions are strictly decreasing on [0,π2][0,π2] a upper(lower) bound for cotψcot⁡ψ will produce a upper(lower) bound for cosψcos⁡ψ after a straightforward transformation. This quotient can be bounded above and below by applying the triangle and the reverse triangle equality:

∣∣∥f1∥−∥d1∥∣∣∥f2∥+∥d2∥≤∥f1+d1∥∥f2+d2∥≤∥f1∥+∥d1∥∣∣∥f2∥−∥d2∥∣∣.|‖f1‖−‖d1‖|‖f2‖+‖d2‖≤‖f1+d1‖‖f2+d2‖≤‖f1‖+‖d1‖|‖f2‖−‖d2‖|.
Given these bounds for vectors d1d1 and d2d2 with length ∥d1∥‖d1‖ and ∥d2∥‖d2‖ we now need to find among all possible vectors those pairs which are consistent with the closeness constraint and produces the largest(smallest) possible angle ψψ. This constrained optimisation problem can be solved geometrically using the sketch below:

Figure 5.1: Lengths ∥d1∥‖d1‖ and ∥d2∥‖d2‖ realising largest and smallest angle ψψ

Notice, that

  • the picture respectively the angles are scale invariant. This reflects the fact that Sobol indices and the closeness condition are scale invariant. To avoid clutter by ∥f∥‖f‖ terms, the picture is scaled such that ∥f∥=1.‖f‖=1.
  • All points within the circle of radius δδ represent ∥d1∥,∥d2∥‖d1‖,‖d2‖ combinations which are consistent with the closeness condition.
  • the angle ψ∗ψ∗ is the smallest angle consistent with the closeness constraint, it defines the upper bound. The angle ψ∗ψ∗ is the largest angle consistent with the closeness constraint, it defines the lower bound.

Since any tangent and the radius form a right angle the following relation holds:

sin(ψ∗−ϕ)=δ and sin(ϕ−ψ∗)=δ.sin⁡(ψ∗−ϕ)=δ and sin⁡(ϕ−ψ∗)=δ.
This is true for all values within the first quadrant, i.e. for 0<ψ<π2.0<ψ<π2. If the circle becomes so large that it touches the ∥f1∥‖f1‖-axis then ψ∗=0ψ∗=0 and cosψ∗=1cos⁡ψ∗=1 which means the bound for the Sobol index has attained its maximum possible value. If the circle grows even further the tangent is no longer a point associated with a maximal Sobol index since points with ψ=0ψ=0 are within the circle and have larger Sobol indices than the tangent. This is covered by the reverse triangle inequality as well, since ψ=0ψ=0 is the case ∥f2∥=∥d2∥‖f2‖=‖d2‖ at which the denominator switches sign and starts growing again. Analogous reasoning applies to the case ψ∗ψ∗ and the lower bound for Sy1S1y of zero. As a consequence ψ∗ψ∗ and ψ∗ψ∗ have to be limited to [0,π2][0,π2] and the final solutions are
ψ∗∗=min(π2,ψ∗) and ψ∗∗=max(0,ψ∗).(5.3)(5.3)ψ∗∗=min(π2,ψ∗) and ψ∗∗=max(0,ψ∗).

and taking into account that

In the same way the lower bound can be determined as

5.2.5 Tightness of bounds

To see that the bounds are tight, just recall that the triangle and the reverse triangle inequality are actually equalities if the involved vectors are scalar multiples of each other. This means choosing d1d1 such that y1=f1+d1=(1+∥d1∥)f1y1=f1+d1=(1+‖d1‖)f1 and d2d2 such that y2=f2+d2=(1+∥d2∥)f2y2=f2+d2=(1+‖d2‖)f2 where ∥d1∥‖d1‖ and ∥d2∥‖d2‖ are determined according to the recipe above, will provide yy where the bounds are attained.
